data.title: Too many update prompts for users - and suggested alternatives.

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
First, let me say I love VS Code. I love the velocity of the project. I love the monthly release plan and the cadence that it moves at.

What I don't like is the *consumption* of these updates at an ever-increasing frequency as a user. The promise of Visual Studio Code is a release approximately once a month. But that's (understandably) not reality, because software has bugs and release have unexpected issues in the wild. Let me start with a summary of release history from the past 12 months to serve as data for discussion:

| Month | Count | Releases | 1.\*.0 to 1.\*.1 release time span |
|-|-|-|-|
| Apr 2017 | 3 | [1.11.0](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.11.0), [1.11.1](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.11.1), [1.11.2](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.11.2) | 1 day |
| Mar 2017 | 2 | [1.10.1](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.10.1), [1.10.2](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.10.2) | 1 day |
| Feb 2017 | 3 | [1.9.0](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.9.0), [1.9.1](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.9.1), [1.10.0](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.10.0) | 6 days |
| Jan 2017 | 0 | (n/a) | (n/a) |
| Dec 2016 | 2 | [1.8.1](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.8.1), [1.8.2](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.8.2) | 1 day |
| Nov 2016 | 3 | [1.7.0](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.7.0), [1.7.1](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.7.1), [1.7.2](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.7.2) | 2 days |
| Oct 2016 | 2 | [1.6.0](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.6.0), [1.6.1](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.6.1) | 3 days |
| Sep 2016 | 4 | [1.5.0](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.5.0), [1.5.1](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.5.1), [1.5.2](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.5.2), [1.5.3](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.5.3) | 0 days |
| Aug 2016 | 1 | [1.4.0](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.4.0) | (n/a) |
| Jul 2016 | 2 | [1.3.0](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.3.0), [1.3.1](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.3.1) | 5 days |
| Jun 2016 | 2 | [1.2.0](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.2.0), [1.2.1](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.2.1) | 13 days |
| May 2016 | 2 | [1.1.0](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.1.0), [1.1.1](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/releases/tag/1.1.1) | 7 days |

<sub>[Data available in GitHub tags](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/tags)</sub>

Can we change how releases are consumed here? I don't think the "stable" channel is living up to the name from a user standpoint. I think the code is mostly stable, but not the *experience*. Users shouldn't get this many update prompts in the normal "stable" install.

I propose the following requirements, as a user consuming updates:
- Should not get a prompt to update **two days in a row** (this has happened many times)
- Should not get a prompt to update more than once a week on a channel called "stable"

A few ideas:
- A "slow" channel, where releases are only posted if they has been no new release in the past 7 days. 
  - This would have eliminated the > 1 per month prompts for not-really-stable releases for 9 of the 10 months they happened in the table above.
- Give users an option to configure a similar lag, not prompting for an update until it has been posted for at least 7 days and not obsoleted by a new point release.
  - e.g. `update.delayDays`, which if configured to 7 days would have the same effect as above.
- Make updates a background post-close operation, simply informing the user in a much more subtle way (0-clicks, auto-dismiss) that an update will occur on next restart automatically.

The bottom line is VS code is a means to an end. I'm trying to do work, and so is everyone else. Update prompts, especially repetitive ones in a short duration get in the way of that and only add frustration. They rarely help me get any work done; it's usually the opposite.

Thoughts? Ideas? Can we improve this?

data.title: Search results show special characters HTML-escaped
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: Version 1.12.0-insider (1.12.0-insider) 9530cf6e2b804c4b986d97f105f88d40ee4d2c47
- OS Version: Mac OS X 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Have a repository with files containing special characters, such as "<", ">", "&" etc. that would normally be escaped as & lt;, & gt;, & amp; etc.
2. Search for a string that contains a special character.

3. Result: In the search results, the character is being displayed as "& amp;" when it should be displayed as "&".

![](https://content.screencast.com/users/Tobbi_/folders/Jing/media/cb2dabc8-e00e-424d-a713-4a5e83159abe/00000176.png)

data.title: Icon shapes broken with rendering artifacts
data.body:
- VSCode Version: insiders build 1.12.0
- OS Version: macOS Sierra

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Launch `code-insiders`
2. Observe how icon shapes are way off

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/81205/25063427/6bd3e5e6-21e4-11e7-8249-8bac1df76a6d.png)

This only started to manifest itself when my insiders build switched to the 1.12 branch. It looks like vector icon rasterization goes wrong or maybe the alpha channel bitmap gets corrupted. Restarting or upgrading sometimes fixes the issue but not always.

data.title: Ctrl+W doesn't work with active window

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
It doesn't work with default key bindings.
When I add `CTRL+W` manually to keybindings.json it works.
```
{
  "key": "ctrl+w",
  "command": "workbench.action.closeActiveEditor"
}
```

Keyboard shortcut editor shows double `CTRL+W` key binding like on the following screen:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/37286/25063341/1d7d2e40-21e2-11e7-8de7-3e724ab91889.png)

So `CTRL+W` doesn't work when we have only one occurrence of `CTRL+W` binding from default configuration.

data.title: Feature request: option to reset “Don't Show Again” preference
data.body:
VSCode’s “top banner” often includes a “Don't Show Again” button. However it's not clear how a user should undo this action.

Would it be possible to save these preferences to the user's workspace settings, perhaps? Then it is easy for the user to undo this action.

An example of a user needing this: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/23314

Created a new django project (1_drf), created a venv (1_drf)

1. Create django app
2. python -m venv 1_drf e:\pyenv\1_drf
3. open 1_drf project is vscode

data.body: When developing for web on a laptop it would be nice to be able to use the client console in vscode to increase productivity by not having to switch between windows so often.

data.title: Import path intellisense is no longer working used to work before.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Mac OSX Captain

Steps to Reproduce:
After the recent update, `import` path intellisense is no longer working, used to work amazing with no extensions.  
In my react project, it even used to suggest `packages` inside `node_modules`. 

Appreciate any help on this.

data.title: Fix Markdown Preview Updating on Zoom / Unrelated Config Changes
data.body:
Fixes #24808

**bug**
Markdown preview updates when you zoom. The root cause is that previews are updated whenever the config is changed.

**Fix**
Extract preview config to its own well defined object. Only update the preview when the keys we care about in the config change

data.title: Zooming Causes Markdown Previews to be Reloaded
Search function names only
data.body:
Would be great to be able to just search within function names for the current project! Ideally it would be smart and work regardless of what language files are present within the project.

Or if this is too ambiguous, allow the user to define "search templates" (similar to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/24008) where s/he can put in their own regexes which will match functions - so e.g. the user could create a template with a `/def $searchterm/` regex, which would automatically populate `$searchterm` based on what was input, and would match all Ruby method names...

data.title: Hover over search result either removes search term or shows "null"
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.12.0-Insider
- OS Version: Linux Mint 18

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create a file `a.txt` and write `abc`.
2. Ctrl-Shift-F to find all "b".
3. Hover over the first search result.
4. It will show either `ac` or `anullc`.

data.title: Building from source - Error: vscode-ripgrep@0.0.11 postinstall: `node ./dist/postinstall.js`
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: win7 x64

Steps to Reproduce:

I am behind corporate proxy if that matters.

1. Configuring build env:

```
"C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Visual Studio 14.0\VC\vcvarsall.bat" x86

set PYTHON=C:\Program Files (x86)\Python271\python.exe

npm config set cache C:\acme\Dev\soft\npm-cache --global 

npm cache clean

npm config set proxy http://proxyuser:proxypass@acme.com:8080

npm config set https-proxy http://proxyuser:proxypass@acme.com:8080

npm config set loglevel silly

git config --global http.proxy http://proxyuser:proxypass@acme.com:8080
```

2. Similar to https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/wiki/How-to-Contribute

```
git clone https://github.com/microsoft/vscode
cd vscode
git checkout 1.11.2
scripts\npm install
```

I get the same result for node 7.9.0 and 6.10.2:

```
npm WARN optional SKIPPING OPTIONAL DEPENDENCY: fsevents@github:bpasero/fsevents#vscode (node_modules\chokidar\node_modules\fsevents):

(current: {"os":"win32","arch":"ia32"})

npm verb stack Exit status 1
npm verb stack     at EventEmitter.<anonymous> (C:\acme\Dev\projects\node7.9.0\node_modules\npm\lib\utils\lifecycle.js:279:16)
npm verb stack     at emitTwo (events.js:106:13)
npm verb stack     at EventEmitter.emit (events.js:194:7)
npm verb stack     at ChildProcess.<anonymous> (C:\acme\Dev\projects\node7.9.0\node_modules\npm\lib\utils\spawn.js:40:14)
npm verb stack     at emitTwo (events.js:106:13)

npm verb cwd C:\acme\Dev\projects\vscode

npm verb argv "C:\\acme\\Dev\\projects\\node7.9.0\\node.exe" "C:\\acme\\Dev\\projects\\node7.9.0\\node_modules\\npm\\bin\\npm-cli.js" "install" "vscode-ripgrep@0.0.11"

Some other modules are missing, I've tried reinstalling them manually but they all failed:

```

C:\acme\Dev\projects\vscode>npm list > ../a.txt
npm info it worked if it ends with ok

data.title: Really high cpu usage
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: 
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11234139/25054387/2d796a32-215d-11e7-9406-4bc93aba4808.png)


Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open any project
2. See how it rises.

Since the last windows update and Code update(from this morning), I've got a **tremendous** cpu load when using Code.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11234139/25054372/104e8ed8-215d-11e7-8831-0aa8a6f31653.png)
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/11234139/25054359/fbbcf77a-215c-11e7-98f2-a81ee20aff82.png)
(my cpu is supposed to slow down when the load is too high, so it won't overheat, without it, it would peak at around 65%.)

data.title: Feature Request: Windows 10 allow code to run a bash shell in addition to powershell
data.body: I use bash to run things like Ansible in my windows 10 workstation.  currently in Creators update, I can run via PowerShell bash -c "Ansible-playbook exampleplay.yml ".  It would be nice to have vs code to either give me the option to use a bash shell from codes integrated window or process a bash shell command from PowerShell.

data.title: Selenium Python NoSuchElementException Cannot be Caught
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

```
from selenium import webdriver
from selenium.common.exceptions import NoSuchElementException

driver = webdriver.Chrome('chromedriver.exe')
driver.get("https://www.google.com/")
try:
	driver.find_element_by_id('job_send_docs')
except NoSuchElementException:
	pass
```

1. Run the code above which tries to get an element that is not there (this is on purpose).
2. Observe that VSCode does not except the NoSuchElementException

data.title: UI Theming: Extension list buttons override focusedElementOutline
data.body:
Development Environment:

OS: Windows 7 Professional SP1

Visual Studio 15 Community \ C++ Tools \ SDK
VS Code: 1.11.1 March release
VS Code: 1.12.0 Insiders March 14


Dragon Naturally Speaking DPI 14 (Voice/Dictation/Control)

Node: 6.10.1
NPM:  3.10.8

Description Of Issue:

The UI Theming is great ! I'm really happy it seems to work
on themes other than listed in the notes.

One color element that is really great to have is:
"focusedElementOutline"

It is very helpful for tabindex users to be able to get more contrast.

One set of elements I have found so far that override the setting are:

Extension List Buttons:

Install
Update
Enable

From extensionActions.css :

.monaco-action-bar .action-item:not(.disabled) .action-label:focus.extension-action.install,
.monaco-action-bar .action-item:not(.disabled) .action-label:focus.extension-action.enable,
.monaco-action-bar .action-item:not(.disabled) .action-label:focus.extension-action.update {
	outline: 1px solid rgb(14, 99, 156) !important;
}

Removing the outline attribute allows the configurable outline color
to work. I thought it was just the important override but I guess
it's the definition alone of outline.

This is particularly important as the existing button colors
have practically zero outline contrast when focused.

data.title: Node execution hangs when using `inspector` protocol
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: Windows 10 Anniversary Update

Steps to Reproduce:
1. Choose the `inspector` protocol and start an express application. After a few requests, the express application hangs (i.e. browser is infinitely waiting for a response) and on the VS code side, nothing happens and one cannot pause the execution.
2. Choose the `auto` or `legacy` protocol and start the same application, everything works fine.

The app is running against Node.JS version 7.9 on Windows.

Anything I can do to figure out why the app is stuck when using the `inspector` protocol?

data.title: VS Code black screen VMWare Fusion win 8 vm

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description: Work not yet planned for a specific release.

data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: windows 8.1 virtual machine running on VMWare Fusion

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Disable Accelerate 3D Graphics in the vm display setting before booting the vm. Boot and Login.
2. Install VSCode
3. Run VSCode -- screen is black.
4.- Close VSCode.
5. add --disable-gpu.
6. Start VSCode -- screen is black.

data.title: Tasks "No build tasks defined" with `isBuildCommand`.
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.11.2
- OS Version: macOS 10.12.4

Steps to Reproduce:

1. <kbd>cmd</kbd>+<kbd>shift</kbd>+<kbd>b</kbd> to build
2. Observe 
![screen shot 2017-04-14 at 11 18 42 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/463564/25052054/b520b20a-2104-11e7-9965-c6b7c9419204.png)
3. Click "Configure Build Task"
4. Observe `tasks.json`. Is `isBuildCommand` not used elsewhere in `tasks.json`.
```
{
    "version": "2.0.0",
    "tasks": [
        {
            "taskName": "build",
            "isBuildCommand": true,
            "command": "cl",
            "isShellCommand": true,
            "args": ["cc", "-Wall", "-Wextra", "-Werror", "-g", "${fileDirname}/${fileBasename}", "${fileDirname}/${fileBasenameNoExtension}_test.c", "-o", "${fileDirname}/${fileBasenameNoExtension}_test"],
            "showOutput": "always",
            "dependsOn": "clean"
        },
snip...
```
Screenshot of Developer Tools (I don't know how to export console log for you):
![screen shot 2017-04-14 at 11 18 28 am](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/463564/25052113/06798852-2105-11e7-9881-535cfc0fd32e.png)

data.title: Using integrated terminal to cat file with lots of unicode hangs terminal
data.body:
- VSCode Version: `1.11.2`
- OS Version: `macOS 10.12.4`

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open integrated terminal
2. `cat` a file with a lot of unicode. I found it with [this](https://github.com/zapier/zapier-platform-cli/blob/master/src/commands/validate.js) file, but anything with a lot of printed unicode (eg `validate\n#Validating project locally.\n#\n# \u250C\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500\u2500 ...` should work

The terminal window is unable to scroll while the unicode characters are visible. When it does recover, it scrolls normally when looking at previous lines. Scrolling down to the unicode block hangs it again.

Repro Rate: 100%
